I'm just getting started with JUnit, so need a little guidance from
those that have been here before.

In production, we will have things happening in two stages.  The user
will select two data sources and do a "compare" of specific data between
the two sources.  The he can elect to do a "copy" of data from one data
source to another.

I'm doing the copy part, and that's done now (I know...I coded first). 
The compare part is just beginning, being done by someone else.

In the end, I want to be able to run an end-to-end test, where we set
things up, run the compare, and then run the copy.  But until then, I
need to be able to fake out the compare and just my part - the copy
operation.

As I understand it, all test* methods in the class will be run in
whatever order they appear in the file.  What I'd really like to do is
have a testCompare and a testCopy, but I don't think I can do that and
get what I want.

I thought about having something like:

class TestOne extends TestCase {
    public static boolean testCompare = false;

    testStuff() {
       if (testCompare)
          doTestCompare();
       else
          doFakeOutCompare();
       doTestCopy();
    }

    doTestCompare() {
       // really do a compare test
    }

    doFakeOutCompare() {
       // Put stuff in the data source to make
    }

    doTestCopy() {
       // Do the copy test
    }
}

So, I'd really have only one test method that would get called, and he
would pick whether to do the real compare or fake it out.  Later on,
when compare is ready to be integrated, then we'd flip that testCompare
switch to true, and then we would have an end-to-end test.  How would
that do?
